newsitem.title: FRANCE: EP approves programme to combat drug abuse.
newsitem.headline: EP approves programme to combat drug abuse.

text.p: The European Parliament approved on Tuesday a deal reached with the Council after conciliation talks on a four-year action programme to combat drug dependence.
The 27-million-Ecu programme (1996-2000) is designed to raise public awareness about drug abuse and improve cooperation between the European Union member states to tackle it.
When the Parliament gave the proposed action plan -- COM(94)223 -- a second reading in April, it demanded the reinstatement of a series of amendments to widen its scope.
The Euro-MPs complained that the Council's common position had cut the heart out of the programme by insisting that it concentrate solely on information campaigns, data and research.

Under the compromise reached on October 1, Council accepted the Parliament's argument that drug abuse was a social problem which had to be tackled by prevention, through education and the threat of penalties.
Council agreed the programme should include training for former drug users and street-corner action.
But ministers refused to incorporate therapy for addicts into the programme, saying this went beyond its legal scope.
In a side-swipe at the Netherlands, the joint deal rejects the idea that soft and hard drugs can be treated differently from the point of view of prevention.
It recognises that drug abuse in prisons is a serious problem and can in fact turn non-users into addicts.
